unnormalised: **Environmental News: Renewable Energy Gains Traction in India**
normalised: **Environmental News: Renewable Energy Gains Traction in India**

unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26th - India is steadily progressing towards its ambitious renewable energy goals, driven by both governmental initiatives and private sector innovation. Dr. Anjali Sharma, a leading environmental scientist at IIT Kanpur, highlights the significant reduction in solar panel costs, making rooftop installations increasingly accessible to middle-class families.
normalised: New Delhi, October twenty sixth - India is steadily progressing towards its ambitious renewable energy goals, driven by both governmental initiatives and private sector innovation. Doctor Anjali Sharma, a leading environmental scientist at I I T Kanpur, highlights the significant reduction in solar panel costs, making rooftop installations increasingly accessible to middle-class families.

unnormalised: The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) recently announced a new scheme offering subsidies for solar panel installations covering up to 40% of the project cost for residential buildings under 3 kW capacity. This is expected to boost adoption in smaller towns and cities like Patna and Raipur.
normalised: The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (M N R E) recently announced a new scheme offering subsidies for solar panel installations covering up to forty percent of the project cost for residential buildings under three kiloWatt capacity. This is expected to boost adoption in smaller towns and cities like Patna and Raipur.

unnormalised: Furthermore, Rajasthan's massive solar parks, covering thousands of acres, are now contributing a substantial portion to the national grid. These parks not only generate clean energy but also provide employment opportunities in rural areas.
normalised: Furthermore, Rajasthan's massive solar parks, covering thousands of acres, are now contributing a substantial portion to the national grid. These parks not only generate clean energy but also provide employment opportunities in rural areas.

unnormalised: Local artisans are even experimenting with solar-powered charkhas (spinning wheels), blending traditional crafts with modern technology. One such initiative in Gujarat uses recycled materials and solar panels covering just 50 sq ft to power a cluster of charkhas. The Indian government has committed Rs. 2.44 trillion to achieve 500 GW of renewable energy capacity by 2030.
normalised: Local artisans are even experimenting with solar-powered charkhas (spinning wheels), blending traditional crafts with modern technology. One such initiative in Gujarat uses recycled materials and solar panels covering just fifty square feet to power a cluster of charkhas. The Indian government has committed rupee two point four four trillion to achieve five hundred gigaWatt of renewable energy capacity by two thousand and thirty.
